questions.text: Which of the following is true about simple random sampling?

choices.text: It is the sampling method of choice for heterogenous population
Members are selected without specifying any criteria for selection
Every 5th or 10th member is picked at regular interval
Population is first divided into strata then sampled randomly

questions.solution:
In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included. In other words, the members are selected without specifying any criteria for selection.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: A study on the prevalence of diabetes was conducted and the sampling method shown below was used. Identify the sampling method used.
questions.solution:
In this study, the population is separated into homogenous sub-groups and from these, random samples are drawn. This sampling method is called stratified random sampling.

Related Pearl: Sampling

  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about cluster sampling?

choices.text: Clusters are created based on similarities
It is a two stage sampling
It is cheaper than most other methods
It is a method used for rapid assessment

questions.solution:
In cluster sampling, the clusters are created randomly. On the contrary, in stratified random sampling, the strata or groups are created based on similarities.

questions.text: Which sampling method is used for assessing the immunization status of children under the immunization program?
questions.solution:
Cluster sampling is the method of sampling done in immunization programs for assessing the immunization status of children.

Related Pearl: Sampling

questions.text: A research is being conducted to assess the nutritional status of the children in a particular district. For this purpose, 2 children are randomly selected from every school in the district. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.solution:
In the cluster sampling technique, the sub-groups of the population/ clusters are naturally occurring. These clusters are randomly made rather than based on any particular characteristic. The population of children here is naturally divided into various schools without being based on any characteristics.

questions.text: In which of the following sampling techniques is design effect used?
questions.solution:
The design effect is used in cluster sampling to allow for design structure and correlation between clusters.

The design effect (DEFF) is used to decide the sample size needed for cluster sampling. This is done by calculating the difference in sampling variability to the variability expected with simple random sampling (SRS).

It can more simply be stated as the actual sample size divided by the effective sample size (what you would expect if you were using SRS). For example, let’s say you were using cluster sampling. A DEFF of 2 means the variance is twice as large as you would expect with SRS. It also means that if you used cluster sampling, you’d have to use twice the sample size.

Related Pearl: Sampling

questions.text: Simple random sampling is ideal for which of the following study groups?

choices.text: A study being conducted on all vaccinated people of an area
A study on occupational exposure in all workers of the same factory
A study being conducted on prevalence of acute gastroenteritis in all school children of an area
A study on prevalence of hypertension in men aged 50-75 years in an area

questions.solution:
Simple random sampling is ideal for a homogeneous population as the sample would be completely representative of the population and it would eliminate the need for systematization or stratification. Here, workers of the same factory form a homogeneous population.

Option A: For a vaccinated population - cluster sampling

Options C and D: For a heterogeneous population - stratified sampling

questions.text: In a study, first schools were sampled, then sections and finally students. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.solution:
Multistage sampling is the taking of samples in stages using smaller and smaller sampling units at each stage. It involves dividing the population into groups (or clusters). Then, one or more clusters are chosen at random and everyone within the chosen cluster is sampled.

Snowball sampling is a type of non-random sampling preferred in case of diseases with social stigma (eg., alcoholism, iv drug abuse etc).

questions.text: For an epidemiological study, sampling was done as shown below. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.solution:
Systematic sampling involves a systematic pattern to sampling, like choosing every 3rd person from an area or hospital, etc.

questions.text: In a study, subjects were assigned according to the potential factor that will influence the outcome of the study. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.solution:
In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.

For example: If a researcher wants to conduct a research study to determine if alcohol consumption is a risk factor for lung cancer. He must first stratify the population into smokers and non-smokers because smoking is a known risk factor and also smoking is associated with alcohol consumption. 

Related Pearl: Sampling

The given image shows a stem-and-leaf plot.

To construct the above stem-and leaf plot, the given data is first arranged in ascending order. E.g., 44, 46, 47, 49, 63, 64, 66, 68, 68, 72, 72, 75, 76, 81, 84, 88, 106

While constructing the plot, the leaf contains the last digit of the number and the stem contains all of the other digits. For example, for the number 106 the stem contains 10 and the leaf contains 6; similarly for the number 46 stem contains 4 and the leaf contains 6. Following this, the whole stem-and-leaf plot is given below.

Related Pearl: Stem-and-Leaf Displays

  • A stem-and-leaf plot is used to graphically display small to moderate sized data.
  • In this type of representation, the values of the data are separated into two parts, the stem and the leaf.
  • Usually, the stem represents the tens, hundreds, thousandth digits, etc. and the leaf part represents the remainders of the digits.
  • For example, if a set of data containing marks of students of out 100 is 94, 90, 84, 87, 89, 85, 83, 79, 72, 70, 72, 68, 69, 65, 53. Then the stem-and-leaf for this set of data would be as shown in the image.

questions.text: Identify the type of statistical plot shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a symmetric funnel plot.

Related Pearl: Funnel Plots

  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.
  • This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.
  • A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.
  • These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.
  • In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.

questions.text: The plot from the data obtained from a study is shown below. Which of the following results in this type of plot?
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of an asymmetric funnel plot. This usually occurs in meta-analysis due to publication bias or other reporting bias.

Related Pearl: Funnel Plots

  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.
  • This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.
  • A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.
  • These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.
  • In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.

questions.text: Results of various studies carried out to study the role of smoking in breast cancer are plotted below. Identify the plot.
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis.

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: A study was done to assess the risk factors for breast cancer in 100 females from urban cities. A statistical group and analysis are shown below. The values indicate the odds ratio and the 95% confidence interval. How many risk factors may be ascertained from the statistical analysis of the research?
questions.solution:
Among the factors shown in the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant. Hence these 3 factors can be ascertained as risk factors.
 
High socioeconomic status is not a risk factor. Even though there is a positive association, it is not statistically significant. Any association that has a 95% confidence interval range that includes the value of 1.0 is considered to be non-significant. The value of 1.0 in the range means that the two factors may co-exist together but one is not causing the other to happen.
 
Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:
  • OR > 1 indicates a positive association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence limits are also >1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertained as a risk factor.
  • OR = 1indicates no association. Irrespective of the odds ratio, if the lower limit of 95% CI is <1 and the upper limit of 95% CI >1, the OR is non-significant and cannot be ascertained either as a protective or a risk factor.
  • OR < 1 indicates a negative association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence limits are also <1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertained as a protective factor. 
Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question:
Factor
Odds ratio (95%confidence limits)
Interpretation
Early menarche
1.3 (1.2-1.9)
Positive association, significant, risk factor
Age <50 years
0.04 (0.01-0.32)
Negative association, significant, protective factor
Smoking
0.5 (0.02-0.9)
Negative association, significant, protective factor
BRCA mutation
1.9 (1.1-2.8)
Positive association, significant, risk factor
Alcohol
1.0 (0.8-1.8)
No association, non-significant
High socioeconomic status
1.4 (0.5-3.5)
Positive association, non-significant
Obesity
1.24 (1.1-1.7)
Positive association, significant, risk factor
No family history of Ca. breast
0.3 (0.01-0.9)
Negative association, significant, protective factor

The image shown is that of a box-and-whisker plot.

McNemar's test is a statistical test used on paired nominal data. It is used as a transmission disequilibrium test for detecting linkage disequilibrium.

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

questions.text: What is Dixonâ€™s Q test used for?
questions.solution: The Dixon’s Q test is used for identification and rejection of outliers. It is usually used in normal distributions.

questions.text: Regarding the given box-whisker plot, the true statement is:
questions.solution:
The given box-whisker plot represents a positively (or right) skewed distribution.  In a positively skewed distribution, the mean > median > mode.

To further understand and correlate the fact, have a look at the following images:

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median â€“ 2 mean (or) Mean = Â½ (3 median â€“ mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is theÂ median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.
